In the near future, he would like to acquire more land to continue planting alfalfa and increase his sales. This is the first time he takes a loan with MFP as well as his first experience working with a cooperative bank. His promise is to work collaboratively to help his group progress. The funds that he requests will be destined for purchasing fertilizers and to make improvements to some of the structures of his home.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Merelou

texts.en:
Merelou M., 34, is from the town of San Isidro Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Merelou owns and operates a business venture running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products to the local community members. Merelou has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns ~1,800 PHP a month.

In 2008, Merelou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merelou is requesting a loan of 1,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La señora Victoria es socia del Banco Comunal “6 D. Enero”, que esta ubicado en el distrito D. Ilave, provincia D. El Collao, en el departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 47 años D. edad, ella actualmente vive sola que su esposo falleció, sin embargo esta  al cuidado D. 06 hijos, ella tiene estudios D. primaria incompleta (tercero D. primaria).

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace muchos años, es una D. las fundadoras D. su Banco Comunal, su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, monto que le sirvió para adquirir algunas mercaderías para su negocio. 

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional D. S/. 1700.00 Nuevos soles, con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir fibra D. alpaca D. las zonas altas D. Ilave y las venderá en las diferentes ferias D. la región, principalmente en Juliaca.

Su deseos tener una casa en la ciudad D. Puno, donD. podría poner su negocio D. fibra,  y brindarles una profesión a sus hijos para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

A ella le gustan las reuniones y los ahorros.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the 6 D. Enero Community Bank, which is located in the Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department. She is 47. She currently lives alone because her husband died. Nevertheless, she is raising six children. She has a third graD. education. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for many years. She is one of the founders of her Community Bank. She used her first loan of 300 PEN to buy some merchandise for her business. She currently needs another loan for 1,700 PEN. She will use the loan to get alpaca fiber from the high regions of Ilave. She will sell the fiber in the different regional fairs, primarily in Juliaca. Her wishes are to have a house in the city of Puno where she could put her fiber business. She would also like to give her children a profession so that they do not have economic problems in the future. She likes the meetings and the savings (of her Community Bank).

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy alpaca fiber

loans.name: Anne Kwamboka

texts.en:
Anne is married and runs a bookstore as her primary business. She also does farming on the side. She has been in the bookstore business for the past five years and she is able to earn a profit of 7000/= per month.

Anne has never borrowed from any financial institution before. She has applied for a loan which she hopes to use a part of to add more stock in her shop and also to buy fertilizer and other chemicals for her secondary business which is farming.

Anne plans to build a bigger bookshop in the future.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To add more books to her shop and to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Uurtsaih

texts.en:
Ts. Uurtsaih is 38 years old and lives with her husband, son and daughter in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Their home is a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her children currently attend the local high school. Uurtsaih operates a mobile grocery store that sells products to people who live in her area. She transports food from the capital to the countryside and sells directly to farmers and herders. She then purchases raw goods from herders, and transports them to Ulaanbaater, Mongolia's capital city, for sale. 

Uurtsaih started her business in 2000 and has been successful. She works hard everyday to expand her business and hopes to provide a high-quality life to her two children. It is her dream that both become well-educated, good people. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug ($1,425) loan to buy supplies and storage space for her business.

loans.use: to buy supplies and storage space for her grocery business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: achat de porcs

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es: Nelly  es una mujer trabajadora que lucha por sus ideales, vive en el distrito de Manantay, región Ucayali, tiene 49 años de edad, es  madre de seis hijos, de los cuales cuatro son mayores de edad.  Nelly se dedica a la  venta de tablas y listones de madera, actividad que lo realiza junto con su esposo, este negocio funciona en su casa. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Loreto” desde hace tres años, el primer préstamo que recibió fue de 300 soles que le permitió invertir en frutas para vender en la vereda de su casa, en la actualidad ella necesita un crédito de 2000 soles que será utilizado para comprar madera y venderlo posteriormente. La meta de Nelly es tener un local propio para colocar las tablas y seguir progresando.
texts.en:
Nelly is a hardworking woman who fights for her ideals. She lives in the District of Manantay in Ucayali Region. Nelly is 49 years old and the mother of 6 adult children. She and her husband sell tables and wooden slats from their business that they operate out of their home.

Nelly joined the Communal Bank “Loreto” three years ago. The first loan she received was in the amount of 300 soles and used to buy fruit that she sold from the sidewalk near her home. At the moment, she needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy wood for resale. Nelly’s goal is to have her own store where she can sell tables and move her business forward.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood for resale

loans.name: Si Se Puede 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Carolina, 29, is from Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Si Se PueD. (Yes You Can), and her story is representative of the other borrowers of the group.

Carolina lives in a part of Santo Domingo called Guaricanos VilL. MelL., one of the poorest parts of the capital. Here, running water (never potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Despite these difficulties, Carolina runs a successful business selling clothing to her friends and neighbors. Unlike many others who sell packets of used clothing, Carolina only buys new clothing to sell. With this loan she plans on buying two dozen blouses, six dozen pairs of pants, and also a new case of perfumes. 

This is Carolina’s second loan with Esperanza International. She appreciates the opportunity of financing that her business now receives. Carolina’s dream is to have a business big enough that she will need to hire two or three employees. For her family, she hopes to one day build a house that they can call their own. Thank you for lending to Carolina and the Si Se PueD. group!

loans.use: Blouses, pants and perfume

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is 29 years old and married with two children, one of whom is four and the other of whom is eleven. Both of her children go to school. She resides and rents a one room house in which she is staying with four people. She and her family have no access to electricity and no running water. They have only two meals a day. 

Zaituni works in a semi urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She has a stall selling fish. She works seven days a week and receives an average of 30 customers a day; she sells to all sorts of people. Her major business challenges include the ever increasing price of fish and the rainy season, which reduces her number of customers. 

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, medication and rent for her residence. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years. She is servicing her tenth loan. Regina joined MCDT because it was easy to work with and near her home. She wants to use this latest loan to buy more baskets of fish. She aspires to expand her business, to start going directly to fishermen, and to own an area in which she can permanently place her business.

loans.use: purchasing more baskets of fish

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip G. is 27 years old and married to Veronica Wanjiru. He has been in the general merchandise retail business for the last two years.

This is Philip’s second loan from KADET. He used the first loan to rent his current business premises since before that he used to do hawking door to door. He has never borrowed from any micro-finance institution before. He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a KADET client.

Philip will use this loan to further expand his current business premises (set up more shelves, improve the lighting, and restock his merchandise) so as to meet the high demand during the Christmas season. His future dream and aspiration is to own a supermarket and improve his quality of life.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: expand his business premises by setting up shelves, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is sixty years of age. She is divorced and the mother of two children who are both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the major occupation of the people is mainly fishing. Mary is a trader. She runs a provision store by the roadside in the community. She procures her goods from Accra. According to Mary, she has been in business for over thirty-five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions.

loans.name: Vero

texts.en:
Vero sells flour and charcoal at the market. She has been in this business for five years. She lives in Warri, Delta State. She is 53 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a civil engineer.

Vero hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN which she will use to invest in her business, buying in bulk to get a better price. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more flour and charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Helenita

texts.en: Helenita E. is from the village of Carmen, Cagayan de oro City. She is 40 years old. Helenita is widowed and has one adult child. To make a living, Helenita runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Helenita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Helenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Helenita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Helenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en:
Marivel F. is from the village of Estaka. She is 33 years old and married. To make a living, Marivel owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling surplus clothing products in the local community. Marivel has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marivel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marivel is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marivel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the business and general living conditions of her  family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old and married with five children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Sarah owns a mini-bakery selling chapatti, samosas and pancakes in Mengo Kitawuluzi. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying cooking oil, baking flour and cowpeas at Owino market. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy and open place.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her 13th loan working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerry cans of cooking oil, cartons of baking flour and sacks of cowpeas. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy more flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Plan For Real Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Plan For Real' group from the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown, where 'Shine on Sierra Leone' has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are seeking a loan of SLL 2,400,000 from Kiva lenders for the second time. With the help of their previous Kiva loan, these entrepreneurs were able to expand their businesses. They made more profit and consequently improved their living conditions.

Aminata S. on the left in the picture is the leader of this group. The 24-year-old was born in Waterloo, is married to a businessman, and they have two children. One of Aminata’s children is in class 4 and the other is in Junior Secondary School III. For more than 10 years now, Aminata has been selling soft drinks, stout, beer and canned drinks. With her share of this loan, she will buy crates of drinks to add to her current stock.

loans.use: buy crates of drinks to add to her current stock

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 64 years old, married and has 5 children.  Her youngest child is 25 and is doing fine. She is a trader; she sells fruit juice, bottled water and drinks at her shop in front of the house where she and her family live in Lagos. She started this business 28 years ago. 
She manages the business with her husband who is a retired officer. 

She is requesting a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drinks, fruit juice, and bottled water to sell to increase her profits. This will enable her to expand her business and sell wholesale and retail in the future. She thanks Kiva for their wonderful support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, fruit juice, and bottled water to sell.

loans.name: Hadaf-E-Nek Group

texts.en:
Palwasha is the group leader of Hadaf-e-Nek Group. She lives in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 35 years old and is married with seven children.

Palwasha is a carpet weaver and, through her business, she earns money to support the essential requirements of her family members.

Palwasha wants to expand and progress her business and for the purpose of increasing her business and adding to her monthly income she wants to receive this Kiva loan. She thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To complete the essential requirements of her business

loans.name: Nergincita

texts.en:
Nergincita B. is from the village of Dampil, Lag. Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Nergincita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Nergincita owns & operates a specialized retail business buying and selling dried fish in the local community. Nergincita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nergincita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Nergincita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nergincita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Rokhsar Group

texts.en: Kamela is the leader of Rokhsar group. She is married, 54 years old, and she has four children. Two sons and two daughters are in university. Her oldest son has the decision to support his father in his business. His business is selling fresh fruit and vegetables in a shop, so Kamela wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. He wants to rent another shop, next to his old one, and to expand his business. He wants to support his family. He wants to thank the Kiva lenders and AFS in Afghanistan that help with poor people of Afghanistan.

loans.use: He wants to expand his business.

loans.name: Lukondo Group

texts.en:
Meet Ismail Y. and the Lukondo Group. Ismail is 30 years old and has two small boys. They go to school and so does Ismail's 16-year-old younger brother who he supports.  For the past 9 years, Ismail has run a small business selling cakes and renting decorations for weddings and other events.  He starts work around 8am and can work as late as midnight if he needs to collect his decorations from a party.  Ismail's profit varies depending on the number of events he services, but it can be as much as 400,000 TSH a month (about $270). He will use this loan to purchase decorative light bulbs and cloth to improve the selection of products that he can rent.  Ismail will save any profit from this loan so that he can buy more decorative equipment and a car, which will help him transport the rental equipment more easily.  Eventually Ismail would like to build his own house.

Ismail is the President of the Lukundo Group, which means love in Kipale, one of the many indigenous languages spoken in Tanzania.  The group's members run a variety of businesses such as a saloon, a café, and sales of food, charcoal, clothes and hardware.  They will hold each other accountable for paying back this loan.  

In the photo, Ismail is standing in the back row wearing an orange shirt.

loans.use: To buy decorative bulbs and cloth

loans.name: Mumtaaz's Group

texts.en: Mumtaaz is a housewife whose husband operates a Punjabi food stall called Dahi Bhaley.  Both residents of Multan Pakistan for the past 20 years, her husband wants to buy more ingredients for his food stall for which Mumtaaz bibi is now requesting a loan from Asasah. By enabling her husband to sell larger quantities of food and add more products such as samosas, a very popular item,  Mumtaaz is hopeful that the loan will assist her family in improving their lives.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for Punjabi food stall

loans.name: José Luis

texts.es: José Luis F. Sandí, tiene la edad de 36 años, está casado, y tiene 2 hijos que son su mayor prioridad. Ellos tienen 10 y 6  años. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de algunos terneros y su alimentación. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al ganado para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando se vendan. También desea aumentar el número de animales y poder mantenerlos en mejores condiciones, cuenta con un área idónea para el mantenimiento y cría del ganado. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don José tiene varios años dedicado al ganado. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
José Luis F. Sandí is 36 years old and married. He has two children, and they are his greatest priority. They are ten and six years old. He wants the loan to buy some calves and feed for them. He wants to give the cattle adequate maintenance in order to get the greatest possible income when he sells them. He wishes to increase the number of animals he has, and he wants to be able to keep them under better conditions. He has the ideal area for keeping and raising the cattle. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR, and he is very happy with the terms of the loan. José has worked with cattle for several years. In the future he hopes to give his family a better quality of life and greater economic security. He wants to be able to keep growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cattle

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Hong T., 37, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. T. sells meatballs and cooked fish for a gross income of USD 40 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 10 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more fish to produce more meatballs to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to produce more meatballs.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata M. est âgée de 46 ans, veuve et mère  de 7 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales,  elle commença très tôt à faire le petit commerce auprès de sa maman qui vendait des condiments. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle a vite maîtrisé les rouges du commerce. Elle a appris la teinture lors de son exode à Ségou avec une femme dont elle était sa domestique. Elle mène cette activité depuis 15 ans et jouit d’une grande expérience et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due non seulement à la qualité de la teinture mais également à celle du tissu.
Pour faire de la teinture, elle dilue différents produits de teintures modernes et traditionnels dans de l’eau chaude ensuite elle trempe les tissus blancs  dans cette eau pour leur donner la couleur désirée. Les tissus teintés sont étalés sur une corde pour séchage. Ensuite elle les amène chez le couturier. Les habits une fois cousus sont  blanchis et soigneusement emballés. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est  à son 1er  prêt   qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 2 pièces de bazins moins riches. Elle s’approvisionne sur place.
Madame  Fatoumata M.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de se prendre en charge (paiement des charges du loyer, nourritures et médicaments).
Son ambition est d’avoir plus de ressources pour bien mener son activité car elle a de l’expérience et les clients ne manquent pas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata M., 46, is a widowed mother of seven children. She lives in a big traditional family in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) Not having attended school for socio-economic reasons, she began at a young age to do petty trading together with her mother who sold condiments. After several years' apprenticeship, she was well versed in that commercial activity. She learned dyeing during her stay in Ségou from a lady for whom she was working as a maid. She has been working in this trade for 15 years and has a lot of experience and is well-known. Her strength in sales is due not only to the quality of her dyeing but also of her cloth. To do her dyeing, she dilutes the various products used for modern and traditional cloth dyeing in hot water. Then she soaks the white fabrics in this liquid to give them the desired color. Then the dyed cloth is hung out on a line to dry. After that she brings them to the seamstress and once the clothes are sewn, they are washed and ironed and carefully wrapped. Wishing to grow her working capital so as to make more profit, she came to Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first loan which she intends to use to buy two "less rich" lengths of "bazin" (damask). She buys the cloth where she works. Mrs. Fatoumata M. sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of women and men. With this loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 40,000 F CFA. This profit will allow her to support herself (paying rent, food, and for medicines.) Her ambition is to have more resources to enable her to do well in her business since she has plenty of experience and clients.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying the necessary supplies to do dyeing

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en: Estrelita D. is from the village of Barangay Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 57 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Estrelita owns and operates a salon providing manicure and pedicure services to the local community. Estrelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Estrelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. Estrelita is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Estrelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.en:
Nurgul K. is 36, married, and has four children. She was born in a low-income family of farmers.  From her childhood, Nurgul was eager to study and after finishing the 9th grade, she continued her studies in medical college. After graduating, she got a job as a nurse in a local hospital. When Nurgul was 21, she was given in marriage and moved to her husband’s village, where she still lives with the husband’s elderly mother. At present, Nurgul also works as a nurse and is held in high respect by her fellow villagers. 

In rural areas, where the salaries are low and often unstable, it’s very hard to live on low earnings.  That’s why, in order to support her family and find an additional means of substance, Nurgul started her business in cattle breeding using an initial capital of 8,000 KGS. Owing to her persistent and hardworking personality, Nurgul achieved success and today her farm has five milch cows, five sheep, and two horses.  

Nurgul plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to add to her cattle. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to give a good education to her children. Also, Nurgul dreams of buying a minivan for her family.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Berna

texts.en:
Berna N. lives in the Kamwokya Kifumbira neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 4 children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her mother).

Berna has a business of selling children’s clothes. She has been in this business for 5 years and she works 7 days a week. Berna sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail. Berna has requested a loan from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more of children clothes like baby shawls, baby bags and nappy liners. 

The main business challenge(s) for Berna include ever-increasing prices of children clothes and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build her own house. Berna lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more children's clothes.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en: Marlyn R. is a 36-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: fishing, fish vending and pig fattening. She lives in Pandan, Brgy. Mahawak, Medellin, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing, fish-vending and pig-fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 24,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Marlyn is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and other equipment. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marlyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending-team page on Kiva to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Reynelda

texts.en:
Reynelda A. is forty years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Tinabalan outside Gingoog City in Misamis Oriental province on the islands of Mindanao. Reynelda runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells canned goods and snacks to the local community. She also buys and sells electronic reloads from several networks like GLOBE and SMART. Reynelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Reynelda joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 3000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jose Ernesto

texts.es:
El señor José Ernesto M. labora para MATECSA como obrero es casado tiene dos hijos a sus cargo.
Este es el segundo crédito que trabaja con CEPRODEL los cuales han sido para mejorar su casa cambio de techo y compra de materiales de construcción para dar una mejor comodidad a su familia por lo que agradece a CEPRODEL  por su agil atención.
texts.en:
Mr José Ernesto M. works for MATESCA as a workman.  He is married and has two children in his care.

This is his second loan from CEPRODEL.  His loan will be used to improve his house, replace his roof and buy building materials to make his family more comfortable.  He thanks CEPRODEL for their ready attention.

loans.use: To improve his home

loans.name: Ashkhen

texts.en:
Ashkhen P. is a widow living with her 2 student sons. She has been trading in tools and electric appliances at "Dinamo" market since 1995. 

Ashkhen’s business income covers the family’s general expenses and one of her son’s university fees. Ashken orders the inventory from a number of countries. With a good credit history behind her, Ashkhen has approached SEF for the first time after identifying it as a reliable lender, offering better terms and personalized service. Ashkhen’s loan will cover the customs fees of her inventory order.

loans.use: To pay custom fees for inventory order

loans.name: Chrisitine Jepkemoi

texts.en:
Chrisitine has operated her pharmacy in Naivasha town for the last six years.  She is 40 years old and married to Joseph Jerop. They have four children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan to restock her pharmacy with medicines that are running low.

In the future, Chrisitine hopes to add a clinic behind the chemist and run them concurrently.

loans.use: To restock her phamacy with medicine

loans.name: Jumapili

texts.en:
Jumapili is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

He has operated a retail business selling kitchen utensils (spoons, jugs and knives) for the past two years, he sells from door-door using his hand cart. Jumapili faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to purchase a 'matatu' (passenger van) in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to start a poultry business, purchase poultry feed and chicks. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To start a poultry business, purchase poultry feed and chicks.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a farmer from the town of Sto. Niño, Agusan Del Sur. She is 56 years old and already a widow. She has eight children to support. 

Josephine plants and harvests rice crops. She sells her harvest to the community. Josephine does her best to provide what her family needs. She works extra hard as most of her children are still in school.

Josephine needs farm supplies and equipment. She is requesting a loan of 16,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner in the Philippines. Josephine says this loan would help her farm in a big way.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma R. is from the city of Calabayan Ozamiz. She is 59 years old. Norma is separated from her spouse and has five adult children. To make a living, Norma owns and operates a general store. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Norma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Norma is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Norma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan L.'s main source of income comes from making and selling banana cue and other snacks. She is 39 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Naggasican, Santiago. Susan has been in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Susan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Genara

texts.es:
Genara es socia del  Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru”, ubicado en el distrito de Yunguyo, provincia de Yunguyo, departamento de Puno, tiene 56 años de edad.  Está casada y tiene 6 hijos.  Genara no pudo estudiar. 
Trabaja  con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 12 años, su préstamo inicial fue de S/ 300.00 nuevo soles, con éste dinero pudo  comprar cinco corderos su actividad consiste en la compra y venta de ganado ovino y porcino, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y trabajos eventuales  en construcción.
Con éste préstamo de S/ 2500.00 nuevo soles, comprará ganado ovino y porcino.
Su sueño es mejorar en su negocio y dar estudios a sus hijos.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal es la capacitación y la ganancia del ahorro.
texts.en:
Genara is a member of the Communal Bank “Túpac Amaru” which is located in the District and Province of Yunguyo, Department of Puno. She is 56 years old, married, and has six children. Genara was not able to obtain an education.

She has worked with Manuela Ramos for twelve years. Her first loan was in the amount of 300 PEN. The money was used to purchase five lambs for her business of buying and selling livestock, such as sheep and pigs. Her husband is a farmer, but he also takes temporary construction jobs.

With this loan of 2500 PEN, Genara will buy sheep and pigs. Her dream is to improve her business and provide her children with an education. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the training classes and the interest from her savings.

loans.use: Purchase sheep & pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase spring and summer clothes

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is from the city of Prenza, Tangub City. She is 37 years old. Josephine is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josephine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. 

Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a motorcycle for better service.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 26 years old, married, and has six children, four of whom go to school. She is currently in the business of selling alcohol. Agnes is requesting a loan to stock more alcohol to sell. In the future, she hopes to buy land with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr: Mariée à un assureur, Massan à 37ans et est mère de 02 enfants. Il ya de cela 04ans qu’elle a démarré son activité(vente des oeufs et des ustensiles de cuisine. L’achat se fait au grand marché de Lomé et la revente  à son domicile. Elle veut avoir sa boutique de vente, assurer un bon avenir à ses enfants, aider son mari et ajouter à cet te activité une autre pour réaliser plus de bénéfices.  Elle à payer  son premier  prêt  sans difficulté et elle sollicite ce second pour acheter des œufs et des ustensiles de cuisines.
texts.en:
Massan is a 37-year-old mother of two children, and married to an insurer. She launched her activity four years ago. She sells eggs and kitchen tools. She buys her stocks at the grand market of Lomé and conducts her sales from her home. 

She wants to have her own shop, provide a better future for her children, help her husband, and start a secondary activity in order to increase her profits.  

She repaid her first loan without difficulty, and is now seeking this second loan to buy eggs and cooking utensils.

loans.use: to buy eggs and cooking utensils

loans.name: Baruela

texts.en:
This is Baruela D. R., 60, a resident of Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Samson, an overseas Filipino worker, and is the mother of four children.  Baruela is a high school graduate who manages her own micro-business to help her husband earn a living.

Baruela operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Baruela's store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. Baruela earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her store, Baruela is requesting a 21,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use it to buy more products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Baruela dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.
 
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: Vakhtang

texts.en:
Vakhtang is a 50-year-old small businessman from Lanchkhuti District, West Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Maguli and 25-year-old daughter. 

Vakhtang owns a vulcanization service workshop in the village. He has been involved in this business for five years. It brings the family on average 550 Laris per month. In addition, he is actively involved in the family agricultural business. They produce and sell dairy products from the milk of two cows. The family also has a plot of agricultural land where they grow maize and nuts. Harvested corn and nuts are sold on the local market. 

With the loan, Vakhtang plans to renovate the workshop and purchase new equipment. As a result of this investment, he will be able to provide better quality service to the customers and his workshop will become more competitive, attracting new customers. An increase in clients will bring positive changes to the family’s income. They will be able to purchase more household items and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To renovate his workshop and purchase new equipment,

loans.name: G.s. Lucia Group

texts.es: Teofila y Cristina conforman el grupo Lucia. Cristina se dedica a la venta de mariscos tiene 44 años, es una persona muy emprendedora por lo que disfruta mucho de interactuar con sus clientes. Ella tiene 23 años de tener experiencia en esta actividad, Cristina tiene  que levantarse todos los días para empezar a ofrecer sus productos su mayor desafío es su salud ya que algunas veces no puede llegar a vender y esto no le proporciona ganancias diarias. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de pescado, camarones, jaibas, conchas, punches y chuletas.
texts.en: Teofila and Cristina make up the "Lucia" group.  Cristina, age 44, sells seafood and is a very enterprising person who enjoys interacting with her customers.  She has been in business for 23 years and gets up every morning to offer her products.  Her greatest challenge is her health because sometimes she is unable to work and this affects her daily income.  The loan will be used to buy fish, shrimp, crab, clams, lobster and cutlets.

loans.use: To buy fish, shrimp, crab, clams, lobster, and cutlets.

loans.name: Chayito Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama "Chayito", porque en el momento de crear el grupo estaban entusiasmadas por las olimpiadas donde participaban algunos connacionales y le pusieron el nombre de una de las participantes. El grupo se encuentra ubicado en el estado de México. El grupo esta conformado por 11 integrantes. La señora Maria es la presidenta del grupo. Tiene 41 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de cosmeticos y costuras. En esta ocasion solicita el prestamo para invertir y así adquirir un mayor numero de productos y materias primas para su venta y fafricacion de sus costuras en un precio más economico y poder solventar las necesidades de sus clientes y al mismo tiempo adquirir un mayor prestijio y poder expander su negocio. Con el prestamo va a comprar tela, hilos y cosmeticos para su negocio. Al solicitar este prestamo se siente muy contenta ya que se siente apoyada.Con las ganancias seguira invirtiendo en más mercancia y también para apoyar en su hogar con los gastos economicos. Observaciones La señora que aparece en la foto y no forma parte del grupo tiene sueter azul con una bolsa negra, es hermana de una de las integrantes que quizo salir en la foto.
texts.en:
This group is called "CHAYITO" because at the time it was set up the members were Olympic games enthusiasts and they wanted to name themselves after one of the participating athletes.  The group is based in the state of México and comprised of 11 members.  Mrs. María is the president.  She is 41 and sells cosmetics and is a seamstress.  On this occasion she is requesting a loan to buy more products to sell and raw materials for her dress-making.  She wants to pay lower prices, help meet her customers' needs and also acquire more prestige to expand her business.  

She plans to use the loan to buy fabric, thread and cosmetics.  She is happy about the loan because she feels supported.  With her earnings she will continue to invest in merchandise and also help cover household expenses.  Observations:  In the photo, the lady in the blue sweater is the sister of one of the group members who did not want to appear in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread and cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Analiz

texts.en: Analiz is 20 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single and has a shop that sells green bananas and coconuts for copras (the fried, white flesh of the coconut). She has had this business for a year. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy green bananas and coconuts to sell. Analiz has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Analiz hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy green bananas and coconuts to sell

loans.name: Adalia Sabina

texts.es:
Adalia es parte de la junta directiva de la empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancomazul.
Ella está solicitando en este momento un préstamo de ₡ 400 000 (cuatrocientos mil colones) , para la compra de una computadora portátil  y de una impresora multifuncional para facilitar las operaciones de crédito de la empresita. 
Ella asegura que la que esta empresita la ha ayudado mucho a salir adelante con proyectos productivos y desea mejorar el servicio a las socias de ECC Bancomazul.
texts.en:
Adalia is part of the Bancomazul Communal Bank’s governing board.  At this time she is asking for a ₡ 400 000 (four-hundred thousand colones) loan to buy a portable computer and a multifunctional printer to facilitate the bank’s loan operations.

She assures that the bank has helped her much to get ahead with productive projects and wants to improve services for members of the Bancomazul communal bank.

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Samoun

texts.en: Samoun, 41 year old, is a farmer with her husband. Their income is $6 per day. She has three children. All of the children are studying. Every month she has to spend $32 on food, $20 on school fees, $10 transportation, and $15 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a rice-throwing machine for planting the villager's rice seed to get some income. In the future, she wants to buy a hand tractor for doing plowing of the villager's farm if she has enough money. For her children, she will try to support them to study and at least finish high school.

loans.use: To buy a rice-throwing machine

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a basket-making business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase bamboo and other materials for her basket-making business.

Teresita has been in this business for 25 years.

In the future, Teresita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo and other materials for her basket making.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 34 years old, married and has three children. For four years he has been operating a van transport business. He has employed one person to assist him in the business. He left his job and went into business so that he could earn a better income for his family. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to improve his business.
Samuel hopes to buy two more vans for more income generation. He has requested 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy a new engine for his van.

loans.use: To buy an engine for his van

loans.name: Nigina

texts.ru: Нигина проживает в районе Дангары. Ей 36 лет. Она вдова. У нее трое детей. Двое ее детей учатся в средней школе, а другой ребенок у нее маленький. Нигина имеет среднее образование. Она предоставляет услугу, занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Кредит берет для приобретения электрической швейной машинки.
texts.en: Nigina lives in the Dangara district.  She is 36 years old, a widow and has three children.  Two of her children attend a secondary school, and her other child is still small.  Nigina has a secondary education.  She provides a service and sews national dresses.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of an electric sewing machine.

loans.use: to purchase an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.es: La señora Lourdes tiene una tienda de abarrotes y su esposo es chofer y maneja  un vehiculo propio. El crédito lo requiere para la comprar al por mayor productos como ser arroz, fideo y dulces para surtir su tienda. Es la fuente de ingresos que tiene para cubrir sus gastos. Vive en la casa de sus padres la misma queda  ubicada en la zona Valle Hermoso de la ciudad de La Paz; es casada y no tiene hijos. Lourdes es cliente desde el año 2008 y esta es la tercera vez que su préstamo se canaliza a través de Kiva.
texts.en:
Sra. Lourdes has a grocery store. Her husband is a chauffeur and drives his own vehicle. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy products in bulk such as rice, noodles, and candy so that she can restock her store. This is the source of income that helps her to cover her expenses. Lourdes lives with her parents in the District of Valle Hermoso in the city of La Paz. She is married and has no children.

Lourdes has been a client since 2008 and this is the third time that her loan has been referred to Kiva for funding.

loans.use: to buy rice, noodles, candy, and other products in bulk.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Raising hogs is Valentina's primary source of income. She has been in this activity for one year. When the hogs are ready for disposal, Valentina sells them to the butchers who come down into their village. She usually earns 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) for each hog.

Valentina is now 43 years-old and was proud to give a good education for her one child through the income she generated from her business.  

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy feed and vaccine for the hogs to ensure proper growth and good nutrition. 

In the future, she would like to strengthen her hog raising business in order to save for future expenses, especially as she gets older and older.

loans.use: to buy vaccine and feed to raise to for her business

loans.name: Theresia Mukayili

texts.en:
Theresia is a married woman. She has 4 children with ages ranging from 8 years to 15 years. She describes herself as patient. 

She operates a cereals sales business where she sells beans, rice, millet, groundnuts and other cereals. She has been involved in this business for 1 year. Her business is located at a shopping centre in Kakamega and her primary customers are the local people and students at a nearby university. She describes her biggest business challenge to be financial constraints. She will use the Kes 10,000 loan to add to her stock of cereals. 

Her business goal is to grow it to wholesale within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will give good education to her children.

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina lives in Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of her brother. Madina has been selling charcoal for three years. She works 6 days a week in her business and retails her products from home. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, in order to buy more bags of charcoal. Seasonality and having to deal with defaulters are the main business challenges for Madina. Her business aspirations include selling charcoal on wholesale and building rental rooms. Madina lives in a home that she owns, and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding her family.

loans.use: buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Mor

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié et père de trois enfants qui sont élèves au collège.Il est pêcheur et dispose d'une pirogue motorisée avec des filets.Il va chaque jour en mer et emploie trois jeunes de façon temporaire.La vente de sa production lui procure chaque soir des revenus qui lui permettent d'entretenir sa famille.Il sollicite actuellement un pret de 300000f pour acheter une nouvelle pirogue et des filets afin d'élargir son activité.
texts.en: This borrower is a married father of three children, all of whom are students at the secondary level. He is a fisherman and makes use of a motorized canoe with nets. He goes to the sea every day and temporarily employs three young men. The sale of his catch each evening provides him with an income that allows him to support his family. He is currently seeking a loan of 300,000F to buy a new canoe and nets in order to expand his business.

loans.use: buy a new canoe and nets in order to expand his business.

loans.name: Flor Arllery

texts.es:
Arllery es casada, tiene 22 años, vive con su esposo, su hijo y su mamá.

Tenía dos años de vender sus productos, pero por problemas de liquidez tuvo que suspender su actividad.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo a Fundación Mujer, para reniciar nuevamente la venta de productos.Arllery comprará con el préstamo cosméticos, joyería, artículos para el hogar.Ella normalmente entrega los catálogos a las clientas para que estas realicen los pedidos,entrega y cobra cinco días después.Como ella trabaja con varios catálogos se dedica todos los días entre semana.

Arllery quiere salir adelante ,reiniciar su negocio e independizarse económicamente.
texts.en:
Arllery is married, 22 years old, and lives with her ​​husband, son and mother.

For 2 years, Arllery has been selling her products, but due to liquidity problems she had to suspend her business.  She is requesting a loan from Fundación Mujer (Foundation for Women) to renew selling products.  With the loan, Arllery will buy cosmetics, jewelry, and items for the home.  She usually delivers catalogs to clients in order to complete the orders.  She delivers and collects five days later.  As she works with various catalogs, she is devoted to working all weekdays.

Arllery wants to get ahead, restart her business and become financially independent.

loans.use: to purchase products such as cosmetics, jewelry, lingerie and more to sell by catalog.

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana es socia del Banco Comunal “Kapia Marca” del distrito y provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno, tiene 50 años D. edad, está casada  y cuenta con estudio D. educación secundaria.  Tiene 5 hijos independientes.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace seis años, su primer préstamo fue por la suma D. S/. 300.00 nuevo soles, dinero que incrementó al capital D. su negocio D. venta D. abarrotes, además compra y venta animales vacunos.

Solicitará un nuevo préstamo por la suma D. S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invertirá en la compra D. un animal vacuno para su engorD. (tres meses), también comprará forraje.  En el negocio le ayuda su esposo.

Su sueño para el futuro es tener vacas lecheras y así mejorar sus gnanacias.

Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal son las reuniones y la distracción con las socias.
texts.en:
Susana is a member of the “Kapia Marca” communal bank in Yunguyo District and Province, Puno Department.  She’s 50 years old, married and completed secondary school; she has five children who are all independent.

She’s worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for six years.  Her first loan was for 300 new soles that she used to increase her capital in her grocery store and also in her livestock sales.

She will request a new, 3000 new sol, loan to buy a head of cattle to fatten up (three months) and also to buy fodder.  Her husband helps her in the business.  Her dream for the future is to have dairy cows to improve profits.  What she likes best about her communal bank is the meetings and spending amusing time with her coworkers.

loans.use: to buy a head of cattle and to buy fodder to feed the animals.

loans.name: Maendeleo Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Maendeleo SHG Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Carolyne is the facilitator of the Maendeleo SHG Group. She takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Carolyne had a very good maize yield harvesting twelve bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Carolyne was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Carolyne and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Carolyne will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Maendeleo SHG Group will each plant between half and one acre of maize.
The photograph shows Carolyne and her group with the field officer on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a 60-year-old business man who is married to Mary, a farmer. They are blessed with one child aged 25 years old. Michael has been running a butchery for the past twenty years, earning a monthly income of 20,000 KES which he uses to support his family.

Michael is applying for a 16,000 KES loan with KADET after repaying his two previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to buy a bull for slaughtering and so add stock to his business. With the anticipated profits from the business, he will work to educate his child up to university level.

Michael hopes to open a retail shop for his wife in the near future.

loans.use: to buy a bull for slaughtering for his business.

loans.name: María Asuncion

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo (Manta), este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.

La señora María es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta su grupo porque es muy ordenado y cumplido, tiene 50 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció, pero  de esa relación tiene cinco hijos todos mayores de edad,  dos  de ellos aún viven en su casa ya que aún están solteros.

Ella para poder solventar  los gastos del hogar se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo, sabanas, edredones y zapatos, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes. Trabaja todos los días,  deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada 8 días. Su mercadería la compra en Santo Domingo,  en Quito o en Guayaquil depende de donde consiga más barato. Tiene 15 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: ropa, zapatos, sabanas y edredones.

Sus sueños son tener buena salud y que su negocio siga adelante.
texts.en:
The Honduras 2000 cooperative bank meets every 15 days in the canton of Jaramijo (Manta).  The area is known for the beautiful beaches that bathe the coasts of this beautiful place.  Here, the majority of the residents are very hard working and dedicated to work related to the sea.

María is a founding member of the cooperative, and she likes her group because it’s very organized and punctual.  She is 50 years old and lost her husband several years ago.  However she has five children that are now grown from this relationship.  Two of them live with her because they are still single.

In order to meet the household expenses, she dedicates herself to commerce.  She sells all types of clothing, sheets, comforters, and shoes.  She sells door-to-door, and also from her house where her customers arrive.  She works every day, extending credit to her customers and collecting payment every 8 days.  She buys her merchandise in Santo Domingo, in Quito or in Guayaquil, depending on where she can obtain lower prices.  She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years, and things are going very well.

She will use this loan to buy more merchandise such as:  clothing, shoes, sheets and comforters. 

Her dreams are to have good health and for her business to continue moving forward.

loans.use: buy clothing, shoes, sheets and comforters.

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru: Олимчон 1969 года рождения, у него 4 детей. Раньше он работал пастухом в колхозе, в течении 25 лет набрал опыта по разведению скота, сейчас он занялся куплей продажей скота и каждую неделю перепродает коз. Жена также помогает по хозяйству Олиму, у них есть корова и теленок. Она доит корову, а молоко и молочные продукты продает соседям. Олимчон надеется на дальнейшее сотрудничество и финансовую поддержку и просит кредит для покупки коровы.
texts.en: Olimjon was born in 1969.  He has four children.  He had previously worked as a shepherd at a collective farm for 25 years and gained experience in breeding livestock.  Now, Olimjon became involved in buying and selling livestock and resells goats every week.  His wife also helps Olim with the business, and they own a cow and a calf.  She milks the cow and sells milk and dairy products to the neighbors.  Olimjon relies on continued partnership and financial support and is requesting a loan to purchase a cow.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Hilda Luz

texts.es:
Hilda es una mujer de 47 años, vive en la ciudad de Ica, es una mujer que ha pasado por muchas adversidades, hilda nos comento que hace algunos años lastimosamente sufrió la pérdida de su esposo, desde entonces ella dedica todos sus esfuerzos por sacar adelante a su familia, , ya que a raíz de esta pérdida Hilda saco fuerzas y decidió no dejarse vencer por nadie ni nada, a pesar de no tener una profesion ya que sus padres no tenían los medios económicos suficientes, pero a Hilda le hubiera gustado estudiar la carrera de Enfermería .

Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, día a día Hilda trabaja en su pequeño negocio venta de comida, ella brinda desayunos desde tempranas horas de la mañana, Hilda puede trabajar por un aproximado de 8 horas diarias, ella se siente a gusto realizando su labor y cree que le va bien por el trato amable que brinda a sus clientes. 

Hilda se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de una olla arrocera pequeña, sillas y podrá realizar la refacción de su refrigerador; de esta manera Hilda tendrá su negocio mejor acondicionado para poder seguir brindando sus servicios, así pues ella seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para poco a poco poder ampliar su negocio y así poder salir adelante.
texts.en:
Hilda is a 47 year old woman who lives in the city of Ica. She is a woman who has gone through a lot of adversity. Hilda told us that some years ago she suffered the loss of her husband. Since then, she has put all of her efforts into getting her family ahead. As a result of this loss, Hilda found strength an decided not to let her self be beater by anyone or by anything, despite not having a profession since her parents didn't have enough money. Hilda would have liked to study nursing. 

On her own initiative, with a lot of hard work and dedication, Hilda works day to day in her small business selling food. She offers breakfasts starting in the early hours of the morning. Hilda can work approximately 8 hours a day. She feels happy doing her work and believes that it is going well for her because of the friendly service she offers her customers.

Hilda is very grateful to the Kiva lenders, since thanks to their help she can buy a small rice cooker, chairs and a replacement part for her refrigerator. In this way, Hilda will have her business better set up to be able to keep offering her services. This way, she can keep working and striving to expand her business little by little and in this way get ahead.

loans.use: to buy a small rice cooker, chairs and a replacement part for her refrigerator.

loans.name: Devora

texts.en:
Devora lives in Escobedo Nuevo Leon, her family is integrate by 3 small boys of 18, 16 and 13 years. To Devora her biggest satisfaction is the opportunity to see how her boys are growing and offer them an education because she hopes from them in the future, they will be honest and working people as she is right now. Her husband’s name is Carlos and is a stationery employer, his salary is little and it does not allow him to cover all the family expenses. For that reason Devora began her own business since 2000; her business consists in order shoes sales and her job allows her to pay the children\\\'s studies, for that reason she wants to continue working and increase her sales capacity.

She requires a loan of $200 USD to purchase merchandise, because she can increase her products capacity and also she can increase the variety of them. In a term of 3-6 months Devora plans to return the loan; she thanks your support and affection.

** This text has been translated from the following original business description.

Devora vive en Escobedo Nuevo León, su familia esta compuesta por 3 jóvenes chicos de 18, 16 y 13 años. Para Devora su mayor satisfacción es ver crecer a sus niños y poderles brindar una educación para que en el futuro sean personas honestas y trabajadoras como lo es ella. Su esposo se llama Carlos y es empleado de una papelería desde hace 26 años, sin embargo su salario es poco y no le permite cubrir con todos los gastos de la familia. Por lo que Devora inicio su propio negocio desde 2000, este consiste en la venta de zapatos por pedido y este trabajo le permite pagar a Eva los estudios de sus 3 hijos, por esta razón ella quiere continuar trabajando y aumentar su capacidad de ventas.

Ella requiere de un préstamo de $200 USD para comprar mercancía, porque de esta manera ella puede incrementar su capacidad de productos, además aumentar la variedad de estos. En un término de 3-6 meses Devora planea regresar el préstamo, por lo que ella agradece tu apoyo y cariño.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anna Nkotan

texts.en:
Anna N. is mother of four children. She draws her inspiration from great losses, especially the death of her daughter and that of her senior sister. When her husband was laid off work, she became the bread winner and responsible for their children’s education. With skills acquired in capacity-building workshops organized by GHAPE and the invaluable support offered by Groups and center members, Anna N. succeeded in providing her community with firewood, food-crops, meat and fowls for performing traditional rites.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to stock chicken feed, pig feed, piglets, and table birds. She will purchase flour, sugar, and yeast, and a frying pan (big-size). Her location is a comparative advantage in the production and sale of these commodities. She will provide snacks to the pupils from all the near-by primary schools.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Rearing animals and frying puff-puffs

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Both Thuy and her husband are 44 years old. They have 2 sons whose ages are 7 and 1. The eldest son is a student at primary school. They have 2000 square meters land of sweet potato and vegetables. Their family income is $9 per person/month. Thuy and her husband want to get a loan of $75 to invest the sweet potato field by fertilizer. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: Investing for the vegetable and sweet potato field by fertilizer.

loans.name: Sham’Igul

texts.en:
Sham’igul K. is 42 years old. She has a secondary-level education. She is married and has 4 children. After secondary school Sham’igul got married so she did not have the opportunity to continue her education. She was a housewife and looked after her children. Six years ago her husband and she went to Russia for work. There in Russia, she learned the skills of business, and how to make money. Her husband is working in Russia.

When she came back to Tajikistan, she rented a sell-point in a market. Gradually her business increased, and now she has two sell-points in a market, where she trades with her son. She is selling material for dresses. Sham’igul has more than 6 years of experience. She is going to increase the sales turnover and the range of goods with the loan amount of $875. Summer is a wedding time, and many brides buy dress material for their dowries. This loan helps to increase the range of cloth for dresses. Usually village habitants need to go far away to buy those materials, so now they can save time and transportation costs. She is going to pay off the loan amount in 6 months.

loans.use: To buy cloth for dresses

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is a 41 year old mother of four schoolgoing children, all of whom are in secondary school. For the past four years, she has run a shop selling mainly food items such as maize flour, rice, beans, cooking oil and others. She also rears poultry to supplement her income. Sophia is a recipient of the Youth Self Employment Foundation organized business and entrepreneurship skills trainings. She is in need of $350 to help her expand her grocery store.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: María Elena

texts.en:
Ms. Maria A., 38, is a single mother of two living in her own house. Her children are aged 16 and 12 and both are currently in school. She feels very happy to be able to afford her own home.

Maria owns a clothing store in the commercial zone in Encarnación, Paraguay. Her store sells products such as t-shirts, jerseys, blouses, shoes, skirts and pants. The quality of her products is quite good and she has acquired a number of regular customers since opening her store 10 years ago.

Maria has asked for a loan so that she may buy a greater quantity of merchandise currently on being sold at discount prices. With more merchandise to sell, she will be able to increase her monthly earnings and provide for her family.

loans.use: To buy a greater quantity of merchandise

loans.name: Hamid Allah
