These products are necessary for her food preparation.  Her work is very tiring but it allows her to help her husband with the household expenses.  He has a motor-car (transportation) service.

She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for being part of her dream.  She wants to continue working to improve her son's lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy rice and sugar.

loans.name: Mogesa

texts.en:
Mogesa is a resident and a farmer in Kitale where he has been farming for the last 10 years. He currently employs four farmhands. His farm produces maize, tomatoes and milk, which he sells at the local market. He is married with three children all schooling and earns additional income from livestock trade.

Mogesa has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the loan will improve his family living standards. He hopes to grow the business by buying more dairy cows and venturing into the poultry business in the future.

He says the major challenges remain finances, diseases and low prices for the products at the market.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is a hardworking entrepreneur who sells soft drinks in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to purchase more cases of soft drinks to sell.

Elma has been in this business for 20 years. Elma earns additional income from meat vending.

Elma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more cases of soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Mariéme Cisse

texts.fr: L'emprunteuse est une femme âgée qui vit seul avec ses 6 enfants depuis le décès de leur père.Elle achète des tissus simples et des thioub(tissus teints)qu'elle place auprès de ses clients et récupère son argent au bout de 2 mois.Elle mène cette activité depuis 10 ans après avoir arrête ses voyages de commerce dans les pays de la sous- région faute de bénéfices satisfaisants.Elle sollicite un prêt de 100000F pour acheter des rouleaux de tissus et de "thioub" qu'elle revendra à l'occasion des prochaines fêtes religieuses. Ses bénéfices lui serviront à entretenir ses enfants .
texts.en: The borrower is an elderly woman who has been living alone with her 6 children since the death of their father. She buys regular fabrics as well as thioubs (dyed fabric) which she gives to her customers, and gets paid after two months. She has been doing this for 10 years, after she stopped going on business trips in the subregion, due to a lack of satisfactory profits. She is requesting a loan of 100,000F to buy rolls of fabric and of "thioub," which she will resell during the next religious holidays. The profits will help her take care of her children.

loans.use: to buy rolls of fabrics and of "thioub"

loans.name: Ozodamoh

texts.ru: Озодамох жительница города Вахдат. Ей 24 года. Она замужем. У нее детей нет. Она имеет высшее медицинское образование. Она год проработала в больнице города, гинекологом. На сегодняшний день она занимается животноводством. Разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается три года. Она берет кредит для закупа скота.
texts.en: Ozodamoh lives in the city of Vahdat.  She is 24 years old, married and has no children.  She has a higher medical education and spent one year working as a gynecologist at the city hospital.  Today, she is involved in animal husbandry.  She breeds livestock for future sale.  Ozodamoh has been in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction materials for building a toilet facility.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy motorcycle parts such as a wheel and a chain, and also to purchase feed for a hog-raising business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng (in the photo) and his wife, Leab, have been married since 1999 and have three sons who are in school. They live in a village along National Road 2, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Seng is a construction worker. His wife sells Khmer noodle, or Num Banh Chok, which are considered the national dish of Cambodia and can be served with a green curry soup and banana flowers, bean sprouts, water lily stalks and cucumber.

Seng is requesting a loan of $500 USD to build a restroom for his family to use.

loans.use: to build a restroom for his family's use.

loans.name: Ishaq

texts.en: Ishaq is a 56-year-old man. He is married and has five daughters. He works in a carpet sales store, receiving a decent salary. Ishaq wants to purchase new home furniture such as bedroom furniture and living room furniture to replace the old one in order to improve his family living conditions. However, the amount of money he has isn't enough to pay for this purchase, so he needs to take out a loan in the amount of $2,000 from FATEN. When Ishaq gets the loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, he will be able to pay for the new home furniture which will fulfill his family needs and provide them with better and healthier life conditions. Ishaq is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase new home furniture.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa sells banku, popularly called “etew,” in Cape Coast at Ayensudu, near Elmina. She is a widow and has six children. She sees to the well-being of her home. Theresa has been selling banku for some time now.  She will use her loan to buy more bags of maize. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
This is Elena, a 47-year-old resident of Pasay City, Philippines, who is married to Alfredo, a mechanic, and mother to her children. She, with the assistance of her family, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elena is a mineral water distributor, purchasing mineral water in containers from wholesalers, and then selling them per container (5 gallons per container) for a profit. She earns additional income by selling personal products such as Avon, Natasha and other direct-sales products. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan to bU. more stocks of mineral water and other personal merchandise to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Elena dreams of being able to give her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work. She also hopes to have a growing network of customers. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of mineral water and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La Sra. Yolanda pertenece al Banco Comunal “Alisson II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Tiene 40 años, está casada y tiene 02 hijos en edad escolar.

Se inició vendiendo productos de belleza por catálogo y ante la necesidad de generar sus propios ingresos y contando con un capital de S/. 300.00 decidió vender ropa para todas las edades, zapatos y otros artículos como regalos, los mismos que ofrece entre sus amistades. Actualmente está por acondicionar un pequeño ambiente en su casa para exhibir sus productos ya que se viene la campaña Navideña y es época de negocio seguro, lo que le permitirá captar a nuevos clientes que pasen por su local, además siempre está en la búsqueda de novedades en los productos para dar diferentes opciones a sus clientes fijos.
Con este nuevo préstamo de S/. 800.00, comprará  ropa para niños y adultos, zapatos y regalos para implementar su negocio, algunos de ellos son pedidos de sus clientes y otros para stock.
Yolanda es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora,  su sueño es contar con un Bazar y que sea un negocio formal para seguir creciendo y agregando nuevos productos para la venta.  Está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle la oportunidad de mantener su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Yolanda belongs to the "Alisson II" Communal Bank, in the Tarapoto district, in the province and department of San Martin. She is 40, married, and has two school-aged children.
She started off selling beauty products through a catalogue. Then, since she needed to make her own income, she used a capital of S/. 300 to start selling clothing for all ages, as well as shoes and other items such as gift items. She sells these to her friends. She is now getting ready to set up a small space in her home to showcase her products, since the Christmas season is coming up and business will be good. This will allow her to gain new customers as they walk by her location. She is always looking for new products in order to offer her usual customers some variety.
With this new loan of S/. 800, she will buy clothing for adults and children, as well as shoes and gift items. Some of these items have been ordered by her customers, and others are for stock.
Yolanda is a hard-working and enterprising woman. Her dream is to have a big store and for it to be a solid business so that she can keep expanding and adding new products to sell. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for offering her the opportunity to stay in business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (clothing).

loans.name: Bidii Shg Group

texts.en:
Simon is the facilitator of the Bidii SHG group. Simon and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Simon takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access One Acre Fund’s best prices and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Simon had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Simon was only able to harvest five bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to [Simon and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Simon will invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Bidii SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Simon is pictured with his group members and the field officer, who is on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Arzykan

texts.ru:
Арзыкан 60 лет, замужем, воспитала пятерых детей и является бабушкой шестерых внуков. Арзыкан на протяжении 40 лет занимается животноводством, являющийся основным источником дохода для ее семьи. Имея практический опыт в животноводстве, Арзыкан успешно развивает свое хозяйство, насчитывающее на сегодня 15 овец, 5 коз, 4 коровы, 4 теленка, а также ежегодно обрабатывает 1,5 га земли. Такая деятельность позволяет Арзыкан получать около 5,000 сом в месяц.  
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Арзыкан  обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 75,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительных голов скота. Доходы от кредита Арзыкан планирует вложить в реконструкцию сарая для того, чтобы улучшить условия содержания скота.
texts.en:
Arzykan is 60 years old, married, has raised 5 children and has 6 grandchildren.  Arzykan had been engaged in livestock husbandry for 40 years which has been the main source of income for her family. Having hands-on experience in livestock husbandry, Arzykan is successfully developing her business which today includes 15 sheep, 5 goats, 4 cows, and 4 calves. In addition, she is also cultivating 1.5 hectares of land.  These activities allow Arzykan to earn about 5,000 KGS per month.

In order to further expand her business, Arzykan came to "Bai Tushum & Partners" for the loan of 75,000 KGS to purchase additional livestock headcount. Arzykan is planning to invest the income from the loan into rebuilding the barn to improve living conditions of her livestock.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Minh

texts.en: Ms. Minh is 35 years old with 2 children who are school age. She is a farmer that focuses on growing vegetables for sale. Her business has been run for many years and it creates her main income. Joining SEDA’s credit program in 2007, she has used loans to buy seed, fertilizer and some other items to improve her productivity of cultivation. Currently, she wants to borrow a loan of 9,632,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to invest in her farming .

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer for farming.

loans.name: Muniran's Group

texts.en:
Muniran is a 57-year-old woman. She spends her time at home and fulfills her household responsibilities. She is a very caring woman by nature. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

Muniran’s husband is a very good painter. He gets work on a contract basis and gets a good profit at the end of contract. Muniran is the mother of three children: two daughters and a son who are 32, 25, and 20 years old. Muniran has given them a good education and now her first daughter and son are financially contributing to the family with their work. Her elder daughter is a teacher in a school, and her son runs a medical store and sells medicines.   

Muniran has requested a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s business. With the loan, he will buy medicines in larger quantity to put in his medical store for resale. Muniran hopes that her son's business will be improved a lot after the loan investment. 

Note: In the photo, the woman holding a book (called an Asasah Passbook) is Muniran.

loans.use: To buy medicines for medical store business

loans.name: Miriya Group

texts.fr:
MIRIYA est un regroupement de 4 femmes qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans. Mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants, elles mènent différentes activités qui sont entre autres la vente de tissus, de céréales, de légumes et biens d’autres articles divers. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles à Bougouni ville (Région de Sikasso, République du Mali). 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, le groupe  a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et  est à son deuxième prêt, après avoir correctement remboursé le premier. 
MOSSODIE, assise à droite avec une grande tasse remplie de sorgho, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 6 sacs de sorgho et 5 sacs de fonio. Elle s’approvisionne dans les foires environnantes de Bougouni et effectue ses ventes en détail au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de consommateurs. 
Elle espère sur un bénéfice de 15.000 FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
texts.en:
MIRIYA is a group of 4 women who are either related or neighbors. They are 34 years old in average. Married, and with at least 4 children, they all have various activities like selling fabrics, cereals (like MOSSODIE), vegetables, and many other items. They live in traditional families in the city of Bougouni (Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali).
In order to better meet the needs of their customers, the group has decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. This is their second loan, having successfully paid back the first one.
With this loan, MOSSODIE (the one with a large container filed with sorghum) plans on buying 6 bags of sorghum and 5 bags of fonio. She buys these items in markets around Bougouni and sells them retail, cash or on credit, to a customer base composed mainly of consumers.
She hopes for a 15.000 FCFA profit, which will enable her to pay back her loan and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda is a 26 year old married woman from Al Zarqa, Amman, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to buy new furniture and make her home a more comfortable space for her family. Since Linda is under 30 years old her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for making home improvements

loans.name: Mahalaxmi Self Help Group

texts.en:
Mahalaxmi Self Help Group consists of 12 women from a village in Odisha. They formed a group to help themselves to share their problems and to solve their problems among them. 

One of them is Bidyut Prava, who was selected as their President of Mahalaxmi Self Help Group. The lady standing fifth from the right side wearing a red saree in the photo is Bidyut Prava. Bidyut Prava is 43 years old and is staying with her husband and her only child. Her child is pursuing the intermediate level in science. She hopes to see him as an officer in a company. She has few acres of land in her village and she is utilizing her land in sugarcane cultivation. Her husband is supporting her in this activity. 

She has requested a loan of 3,20,000 INR, which will help her to purchase the required resources for sugarcane cultivation. She says a portion of the loan amount will help her to purchase sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labour charges.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labour charges.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro is a responsible, friendly and very hard-working person; the most important satisfaction in his life is to see his children smiles, because these fill him of force and an inspiration that let him to continue working. He has 5 children, which are studying and others help in the family business, his wife Maria is a housewife, but sometimes also helps in the business. Pedro wants to offer to his children an education and a better quality of life, however he knows that the only way to make it, is working hard every day. He has a groceries store since 2 years ago and every day his sales go improving.

Pedro requires a loan of $250 USD to increase his inventory of merchandise from his business, he comments that his clients are increasing, but he does not have the capacity to cover his demand, for that reason he needs your support and generosity.

** \"This text has been translated from the following original business description.\"

Pedro es una persona responsable, amigable y muy trabajadora; la satisfacción más importante en su vida es mirar las sonrisas de sus hijos porque lo llenan de fuerza y de inspiración para seguir trabajando. Tiene 5 hijos, los cuales algunos se encuentran estudiando y otros ayudan en el negocio de la familia, su esposa Maria es una ama de casa, pero algunas veces también ayuda en el negocio. Pedro desea ofrecer a sus hijos una educación y una mejor calidad de vida, sin embargo sabe que la única manera de hacerlo, es trabajando todos los días. Tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace ya 2 años y cada día sus ventas van mejorando.

Pedro requiere un préstamo de $250 USD para aumentar la existencia de mercancía de su negocio, comenta que sus clientes se están incrementando y no cuenta con la capacidad para enfrentar esta demanda, por lo que necesita de tu apoyo y generosidad.

loans.use: Purchase Merchandise

loans.name: Christopher Njeh

texts.en:
Christopher is married to two wives and father of five surviving children (out of seven). Thoughts that economic hardship had a hand in the death of his children is a motivation to work hard in order to increase family income.

From two previous loans he succeeded in providing electronics services (radios, calculators) to his community and in repaying the loans. Given a loan of $200, he plans to buy chemicals and parts.

He believes his business will succeed because people will not need to travel to the town of Bamenda to have these services. He also intends to cultivate vegetables which are used in every household on a daily basis.

He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Gardening and Electronic repairs

loans.name: Yeabu

texts.en: Yeabu is the elected leader of the business women's association in the Kabala Market. She encourages women to get organized and they help each other to manage their businesses. A business women herself, she runs a grocery shop in the open market in town. Yeabu is married with four children, and her husband is employed, but his earnings are insufficient to meet the family's needs alone. Yeabu’s business income supplements family finances and she would like to diversify her business. She would like to use the funds for purchasing utensils to increase her stock.

loans.use: Yeabu would like to purchase kitchen utensils to diversify her stock for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Isa Malado

texts.en:
Isa Malado K., 42, has three children. He is a hardworking man who started his business in 1986, but it was destroyed during the civil war. After the war, he started the business again selling food stuffs. After he made some profit, and with his previous loans from SMT, he diversified his business to include the selling of sandals and T-shirts.

Isa runs the business with his wife and they are working together to improve their livelihood. She sells some of the items in the neighboring villages. Their aim is to have enough capital so that they can purchase the majority of their goods wholesale for better profit.

Isa also plans to sell some items wholesale to small vendors who are unable to buy items from Freetown or Guinea due to lack of sufficient capital themselves. Isa is therefore requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: Purchase stock of clothes wholesale

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
"I hope to build a protective fence around my home because I have little kids and I feel that they would be safer this way." I am requesting $500 dollars to put up this fence.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

“Tengo la intención de levantar una barda en mi vivienda ya que tengo hijos pequeños y siento que estarían más seguros” Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para poner una barda en mi vivienda

loans.use: Construct a protective fence.

loans.name: Chiv

texts.en: Mrs. Chiv E., age 46, and her husband, age 49, are farmers on a rented plot of land, earning $3 per day collectively. ThE. have eight children: two make incense sticks used for worship at the Buddhist temple, two work at a pharmacy in Phnom Penh making $7 per day together, two are students, and two are unemployed. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a plot of farmland so that thE. no longer have to pay rent out of their monthly earnings. In the future, she would like to save her earnings to start a business raising and selling pigs.

loans.use: To purchase farmland so that they no longer have to rent.

loans.name: Orziniso

texts.en: Orziniso D. is a mother of 5 children.  She has worked selling clothing in a bazaar for 10 years and is an active client of MicroInvest.  She is a teacher and works in the bazaar after school to supplement her income, as her teacher's salary is too little to support her big family.  Ms. D. is requesting a loan of $1100 to increase her stock.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Hellen's Group

texts.en: Hellen has a small retail shop. She sells home products like soap, sugar, flour, salt, and many more. She wants to buy a fridge with the extra profits.

loans.use: To add more stock and buy a weighing scale

loans.name: Tiira Road C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sylvia N.. She is currently in the business of chacoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Sylvia is 30 years old and is married. Her husband repairs bicycles. She has 7 children ranging in age from 1.5 to 16, and 6 of them go to school. Each week, Sylvia makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Sylvia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sylvia is joined in her small group by Scovia A., Jane A. and Jesca A.. Scovia A. has a business selling ripe bananas and wants to expand her business with the loan. Jane A. is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to add to her stock. Jesca A. also operates a business selling matooke and wants to expand it through a loan..

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Zaina's Ngagu B Group

texts.en:
Zaina O. is a member of this subgroup and owns a beauty salon. She is 32 years old and married with 3 children ranging from age 4 to 16. Zaina began her business in 1998 and runs the business each day from 8 AM to 8 PM. Her monthly profit is 70,000 Tanzanian Shillings (about $65) and she is requesting a loan to buy more salon equipment.

Zaina is joined in this subgroup by Sadaka H., Amina M., Zuhura S., and Swaumu M.. Sadaka H. is currently operating a business in selling cosmetics. Amina M. is currently operating a business in food vendoring. Zuhura S. operates a business of food vendoring. Swaumu M. owns a café.

loans.use: To buy salon equipment

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi D. is a fishmonger and also prepares and sells other food items. She is married and has 3 children. She buys fish, processes them, and sells them to her customers. Her business is doing well and she wants to increase her sales by purchasing more fish.

Esi Duman is asking for a loan of $425 to buy more fish for processing and selling.

loans.use: To buy more fish for processing and selling

loans.name: Félix

texts.es:
Felix is a young father who day after day works to provide the best to his 1 year old and 1 month old children. Since he was a young boy he has dedicated himself to working as a tailor and all this effort and sacrifice have served him well and with his savings he bought a second hand sewing machine and this is how he began to make articles for cars. Thanks to the quality of his products he has seen his production grow and today his earnings have grown considerably and he has been able to acquire another sewing machine. Now his wish is to be able to expand his business making athletic clothing, and he is preparing to make this expansion now.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Félix es un joven padre de familia que día tras día se esfuerza por ofrecer lo mejor a sus dos pequeños hijos de 1 año y de un mes. Desde muy jovencito él se ha dedicado al trabajo de la costura en talleres de confección y todo ese esfuerzo y sacrificio le ha valido para que con sus ahorros compre una máquina de coser de segundo uso, es así que el comenzó a elaborar prendas para autos, gracias a la calidad de sus productos ha visto incrementada su producción y hoy por hoy han aumentado considerablemente sus ganancias y ha podido adquirir una máquina más. Ahora su deseo es poder incursionar en la confección de prendas de vestir deportivas para lo cual se está preparando.

loans.use: Increased capital in order to increase production

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en: Khatira Q. is a 32-year-old woman who has bred calves for meat production since 1989. She lives with her family in the southern part of Azerbaijan, Bilasuvar region. She would like to expand her activity and purchase more calves. Summer is the high season for weddings, which offers the potential for increased sales of meat. As well, meat is very popular all across Azerbaijan. Khatira has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase two calves (each for $300 USD) and fodder for the rest of the $200 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase two calves and fodder.

loans.name: José Francisco

texts.es:
Jose Fracisco C. is a young father of a small son, who is the reason why he makes great efforts to provide the necessary conditions so that he can develop and become a professional.

He is in the bike repairs and spare parts sales business which is located in the El Viejo Town Market in the city of Chinandega.

Like any developing business, his business currently needs to invest in the purchase of spare parts to sell them in his business. With this credit he, along with his small child and spouse, will benefit.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy Juárez, Kiva volunteer.

José Francisco C. es un joven padre de un pequeño hijo motivo por el cual se esfuerza grandemente para brindarle las condiciones necesarias para que este se desarrolle y logre llegar a ser una persona profesional en la vida.

Su negocio es la reparación y venta de repuestos de bicicletas ubicándose su tramo en el Mercado del municipio de El Viejo en la ciudad de Chinandega.

Como cualquier negocio en desarrollo, hoy en día su negocio requiere de inversión en la compra de los repuestos para venderlos en el negocio. Con este crédito se beneficia tanto él como su pequeño hijo y su cónyuge.

loans.use: To purchase work supplies

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a business owner in Tema who trades in lace and satin clothes. She is married and blessed with two kids who are currently in school. Mary provides a great deal of support to her family through her trading business. She has been selling for the past three years but progress has persistently been low due to insufficient funds.

Amina hopes that this loan will enable her to revive the business and make it more viable. She plans to purchase bulk lace and satin clothes to increase her inventory. She believes she would be able to save more to provide her children with a quality education. She belongs to the Gold Trust Group. The group provides assistance and support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase lace and satin clothes in bulk

loans.name: Branka

texts.en:
Branka is from Osječani, a small place near the town of Doboj. She is married and her husband works with trucks and boulders. He earns about 800 KM monthly. Branka works in agriculture: she plants and sells potatoes and corn.

With this loan in the amount of 1 000 KM she wants to prepare her land and to buy compost for the winter. She wants to clean the land and to have it ready for spring. Her wish is to continue with these activities because they can earn enough money for their household.

loans.use: To buy compost and to prepare the land

loans.name: Salvadora

texts.es: Doña Salvadora L., tiene 58 años de edad, es soltera, tiene dos hijos mayores de edad que le ayudan en lo poco que pueden, Doña Salvadora se deica a la venta de Gaseosas y Frescos naturales teniendo un pequeño tramo en el mercadito del Barrio de sutiava, donde tiene 24 años de ejercer dicha actividad, su proposito es poder seguir siendo cliente de nuestra institucion y poder permanecer en el mercado ofertando sus refrescos, su mayor sueño es poder llegar a tener una refresqueria mas grande y poder obtener mejores ingresos, asi mismo poder mejorar las condicones de su negocio y atraer mas clientes, Doña salvadora da inicio en esta actividad como una manera de subsistir y sacar adelante a sus hijos ya que no tenia el apoyo del padre de sus hijos, con el credito pretende mantener un inventario lo suficientemente capaz de mantenerse en le mercado ya que los costos de la materia prima como azucar, frutas estan dia dia muy caros.
texts.en:
Salvadora L. is 58 years old, she is single and she has two adult children that help her out as much as they can. Salvadora runs a business selling soft drinks and fresh squeezed juices from her small stand in the market of Barrio de Sutiava. She has been running her business for 24 years and her goal is to be able to keep running her stand and to expand it to be able to obtain better earnings, and in turn improve her stand and attrack more clients. Salvadora started her business as a way of supporting her children because she did not have any support from her children's father. With this loan she plans to maintain an inventory that will be enough remain in the market, especially given that the cost of ingredients such as sugar and fruit is now so expensive.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Maryan

texts.en:
Maryan has been selling soap in Zanzibar for six months. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy a large amount of inventory to jumpstart her business to a bigger scale than the current business.

Maryan is 31 years old, married, and has three children. Her first born is 5 years old, her second born is 3 years old, and her youngest is 8 months old.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Boiré a 40 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 7 enfants (2 garçons et 5 filles), à Wayerma I, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge, elle a commencé les activités économiques notamment la restauration qu’elle a apprise  auprès de sa soeur depuis maintenant 15 ans. Elle mène son activité  à Wayerma I Sikasso devant le domicile conjugal toutes les nuits où elle est beaucoup sollicitée et appréciée par une clienèle riche et variée.
Dans la souci de maintenir cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle travaille depuis 4ans. Après avoir bouclé huit prêts de groupe ( prêt solidaire)  avec une assocaition de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce deuxième prêt, elle achetera,  40kg de poissons frais, 40kg d’haricot, 40 sachets d’Attièkè, 24 paquets de spaghetti, 20 poulets, 40kg de pomme de terre, 20kg d’haricot vert et un stock de banane plantin (Aloko). Elle achète ses marchandises sur place au grand marché de Sikasso.
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes, des jeunes (célibataires) surtout de noctambules. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Mrs. Oumou Boiré is 40 years old and lives with her husband and seven children (two boys and five girls) in Wayerma I, the main town in Sikasso (the Republic of Mali’s third administrative region). From a young age she has been involved in income-generating businesses, particularly catering, which she learned from her sister 15 years ago now. She runs her business nightly in Wayerma I Sikasso, outside her marital home. She is much in demand and appreciated by a rich and varied clientele. In order to maintain this ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has been working for four years. Having successfully repaid eight group loans (solidarity loans) with an association from her district, she is now on her second individual loan. All previous loans were fully repaid. With this second loan she will buy 40 kg of fresh fish, 40 kg of kidney beans, 40 sachets of attièkè (yam semolina), 24 packets of spaghetti, 20 chickens, 40 kg of potatoes, 20 kg of green beans and a supply of plantain bananas (aloko). She buys her merchandise locally at Sikasso’s main market. The merchandise is then sold for cash or credit to a clientele consisting of women and young (single) people, especially those who stay up very late. She expects to make a monthly profit of CFA 100,000 which will mainly be used to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens, beans, bananas, fresh fish, spaghetti, yam semolina and potatoes

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy S., 39, is married and lives with three children and her husband in Kampong Cham Province. She sells vegetables in the market and is able to make $2 US a day while her husband is a construction worker building houses. Her husband, Ros Thong, 39, typically makes $3 US each day. This couple also gets support from two children who work as garment factory workers.

Soy S. would like to take out a loan of $500 US to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will reduce the cost that he spends everyday on public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.es:
Desde muy joven Jacinta se ha dedicado a crecer en su negocio progresivamente. Empezó vendiendo solo golosinas en una pequeña caja  y como ambulante en un mercado. Luego, además de las golosinas también vendía gaseosas y cervezas, invirtiendo siempre lo poco que ganaba en la compra de mas mercadería

A lo largo de veinticinco años Jacinta no ha hecho nada mas que progresar gracias a su admirable empeño. Ella es sin duda una mujer proactiva y emprendedora. Hoy maneja una gran tienda de abarrotes, en donde por las mañanas también vende carnes y verduras para las compras diarias de sus clientes.

Ella cuenta que nunca ha dejado de trabajar, pues ha sido madre y padre para sus tres hijos mayores. Gracias a su trabajo ella no sólo ha logrado educar a sus hijos, sino también ha construido una casa de tres pisos. 

Su sueño es ver a todos sus hijos profesionales e irse a vivir en un futuro con su esposo quien trabaja en el extranjero.
texts.en:
Since she was very young, Jacinta has dedicated herself to helping her business grow. She started selling only candies from a small box, travelling around the market. After, beyond candies she also sold sodas and beers, always investing whatever she earned to buy more merchandise. For the greater part of 25 years, Jacinta hasn’t done anything but progress thanks to her admirable determination. She is, without a doubt, a proactive and entrepreneurial woman. Today she manages a large grocery store, in which, during the morning, she also sells meats and vegetables for the daily purchases of her clients. She says that she has never stopped working, because she has also served as both a mother and a father to her three older children. Thanks to her job she has not only achieved an education for her children, but has also built a three floor house. Her dream is to see all of her children as professionals, and to leave the country in the future to live with her husband, who works abroad.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her grocery store.

loans.name: Nozimjon

texts.en:
Nozimjon K. is married and has three children whom he is very proud of since they are struggling to get ahead. With the faith that his children would go to college to get ahead, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots to be able to make enough money to pay for their schooling. This is why he started this business 9 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business and that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. Right now Nozimjon is requesting 550 USD for purchasing dried apricots to process and sell. With your help, Nozimjon will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his children went to college and are honorable people.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to expand his business

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en: Augustine A. is 50 years old and is a mother with three children. Two children are currently in school, while the youngest has passed away. She lives at Tarkwa in the western region of Ghana with her family. She has traded in second-hand clothes for the past two years. Selling of used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand-new clothes, shoes, and materials are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore, selling of used clothing and shoes has created a market for many women like Augustine. She sells in almost all of the surrounding markets during their various market days. With the loan, she wants to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's future and also to rent a store to trade in. Augustine belongs to a village bank called ‘Joy’. She hopes to receive 600 GHS to make progress in her business by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy used clothing and shoes

loans.name: Abadatou

texts.fr:
Née vers l'année 1977 et résidant à COTONOU, Capitale économique du BENIN, GBADAMASSI Abadatou est mère de sept enfants tous scolarisés. Abadatou est mariée à DJAKPATA Ali et mène comme activité la vente de de tubercules d'igname, de céréales et de fromages de boeufs.  GBADAMASSI Abadatou sollicite son troisième prêt à ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement afin de mieux satisfaire la forte demande de sa clientèle. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born around 1977 and a resident of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, Abadatou Gbadamassi is the mother of seven children, all at school. Abadatou is married to Ali Djakpata and runs a business selling yams, cereals and cheese. Abadatou Gbadamassi is requesting her third loan from Alidé to boost her working capital in order to better satisfy the high demand of her customers. In Bénin’s local language, Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest.” Bénin is a small country in West Africa, next to Nigeria, with a GDP per capita of $1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to the most vulnerable and is part of a group that is about to launch a micro-health insurance program for beneficiaries of microcredit.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereal, yams and cheese

loans.name: Afde No 16 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 16 ont une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy de Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de cola, légumes, et huile de palme. Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de marchandises qui sont vendues en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25,000 CFA ($50) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE Numéro 16” is composed of five women who average 48 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. These women know one another through ties of community and kinship. They do almost the same work, selling cola, vegetables, and palm oil. They are very experienced and in high demand in these fields.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC, and they indeed repaid it.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of merchandise, which will be sold retail, cash accepted, at the Grand Thiès marketplace.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Santos Angel

texts.es:
el Sr. Santos G. se dedica a la venta de golosinas desde hace 2 años, su cafeteria la tiene dentro de una escuela llamada Jose Trinidad Reyes. que esta ubicada en la misma aldea.
el es casado y tiene 3 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen de el. ella tiene la ayuda de su esposa que es la que le elabora las golosinas que vende como ser tacos, enchiladas, tortillas con quesillo, catrachitas, tajaditas de platano, platanos con frijoles y mantequilla y otras. el es el encargado de recibir el diner, ellos cubren un 100% todos los gastos de su hogar con los ingresos que les deja su negocio, el necesita el credito para poder invertir mas en su negocio ya que no se da abasto con tanto cliente.
texts.en:
Mr. Santos G. has made a living by selling snacks for the past two years. His cafe is inside a school named "Jose Trinidad Reyes", which is located in his town. He is married with three children, two of whom still financially depend on him. He has the help of his wife who makes the snacks, such as tacos, enchiladas, quesadillas, nachos, banana chips, and bananas with beans, butter, and more. He is in charge of earning the money; they cover 100% of their household bills with the income from their business. He needs this loan to invest in his business so that he can accomodate more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase drinks, churros, cheese, butter, tortillas, chicken, pork, flour, beans, and bananas.

loans.name: Le Thị

texts.en:
L. Lê Thị (1412030325) is a 49-year-old female living in the town of Quảng Xương. She is married and has three adult children. L. owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has just started operating this business and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month.

In 2003, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to build a shelter for her livestock.

L. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her 6th loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Sandra Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Sandra Isabel E.  viven en una casa de renta junto con su esposo y tres hijos.
El costo de la renta se ha incrementado y cada vez es más difícil para ella cubrir ese gasto.
Por tal motivo está tramitando un crédito para obtener su propia casa por mediante Infonavit(Crédito Gubernamental) Sin embargo el valor de la vivienda es mayor que el crédito que puede recibir, ya que su sueldo es bajo.
Por ello está solicitando un préstamo para completar el valor de la vivienda y obtener propia vivienda y darle un lugar más seguro a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Sandra Isabel E. lives in a rental home with her husband and three children. The cost of rent has increased and it's harder for her to cover this expense. For this reason she is asking for a loan to get her own home through Infonavit (Government credit). However, the price of the house is more than the credit she can receive, since her salary is so low. Because of this she is asking for a loan to meet the price and obtain her own home to give her children a safer place to live.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Meet the amount of the down payment for a home financed through Infonavit (Government Credit)

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn R., age 21, is studying in college while running a business to make a living. Roselyn sells loads and makes peanut rolls as her sources of income. Her husband is working in a microfinance company. She is from the village of Pinig, Dumalinao, Zamboanga del Sur. Roselyn is married and has one daughter. She has been in these businesses for almost two years and earns approximately 2,000 a month just from them but, of course, she has other sources of income.

Roselyn joined PMPC in 2008 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities of her own. Roselyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 from PMPC. Her previous loan was used to expand her business. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase wallet electronic loads

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Neema M. from Mwanza. She is married and has three children between the ages of 2 and 4 years old. Neema has been running a cosmetics business since 2007. She works at the business for 7 hours per day, 12 days per week. Neema currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase cosmetics in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Neema thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Tek

texts.en:
Tek H., 53, works as a farmer in Battambong province, growing corn. She also owns an orchard of sapodilla trees, which are a kind of tropical fruit tree. H. works so hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for her family.

H. is married and lives with her husband (pictured) who is involved in the business with her too, and they both can earn collectively a typical income of US$9 per day. H. and her husband are blessed with a twenty-year-old daughter who works as a hairdresser in a local beauty shop.

H. wants to take a loan of US$1,200 as her first loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT, to rent a tractor in order to level her farmland to do more corn and fruit-tree cultivation.

loans.use: To rent a tractor to level her farmland

loans.name: Yaneth

texts.es: Yaneth tiene 23 años, es una joven madre de familia que vive en una casa alquilada junto a su esposo Miguel de 24 años y su querido hijo José de 2 años, a quienes desea dar una mejor vida. El negocio de Yaneth es la costura, su trabajo es muy solicitado en su barrio, ya que es la única que realiza esta actividad. Ella aprendió desde muy pequeña junto a su madre y ahora tiene su propio taller, donde atiende con mucha paciencia a sus clientes. Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es terminar los trabajos que le encargan. Lleva 5 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil de su trabajo es tener que trabajar todo el día cuando tiene un pedido muy grande, pues ella es muy responsable y sabe que cualquier tardanza podría dañar su reputación de ser muy puntual, la cual ha ganado con mucho esfuerzo. Para un futuro cercano, espera que su negocio sea más conocido y así pueda crecer más, para ello está dispuesta a trabajar muy duro y sin descanso. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, está muy feliz de haberlo obtenido, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo, ya que no quiere causar problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida y apreciada. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará una máquina de coser nueva, de esta manera espera incrementar su producción y mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Yaneth is 23 years old, the mother of a family, and lives in a rented house with her husband Miguel who is 24, and her dear son Jose who is 2. She wishes to provide her son with a better life. Yaneth is a seamstress and her work is much sought after in her neighborhood, since she is the only one there who does this work. She learned when she was very young from her mother and, now, she has her own shop, where she patiently cares for her customers.

What she likes best about her business is finishing the jobs entrusted to her. She's been doing this for 5 years and considers her most difficult task to be working all day when she has a very large order. She is very responsible and knows that any tardiness whatsoever could damage her reputation for being very punctual, which she has earned with much effort. In the near future, she hopes that her business may be better known and thus grow more. For this, she is disposed to work very hard and without rest.

This is her first loan request from MFP and she is very happy to have qualified. She understands that she must pay it off on time and she intends to do so, since she does not wish to cause problems for her fellow members in the community bank where she is much loved and appreciated. With the requested $700 she will buy a new sewing machine, and in this way she hopes to increase her production and improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUY A SEWING MACHINE

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 45-year-old widowed woman with six children aged 22, 18, 16, 14, 13 and 10 years. Five of her children go to school. Sarah rents a three-roomed house where she stays with all her children. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Sarah resides and works in a semi-urban area.  She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping as she buys the charcoal from Nakasongola, a far-off rural area. The major challenges she faces in her business are transport costs, rainy seasons and intervention by traffic police. She needs to get a document from police that allows her to transport charcoal. She sells her charcoal door-to-door. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Sarah has been in this business for the last four years and has been with MCDT for four years working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock. Sarah is aspiring to see her business grow to enable her to pay school fees for her children and to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To increase her stock of charcoal

loans.name: Amadine

texts.fr: S. Amandine est née en 1984 à Ahovo dans la commune d'Avrankou. Amadine est mariée et mère d’un seul enfant non encore scolarisé. Amadine est maîtresse coiffeuse. Avec les revenus de son activité, Amadine vient en aide à son mari. Pour l'accroissement de ses revenues, Amadine sollicite un crédit d’ALIDé pour améliorer ses prestations et répondre aux besoins en mèches et divers produits de coiffure de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Amadine S. was born in 1984 in Ahovo, in the commune of Avrankou. She's married and the mother of one child who does not attend school yet. Amadine is a hairdressing teacher. With the revenues of her business, she helps her husband. To increase her income, Amadine is seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, in order to improve her services and meet customer demand for hair extensions and other haircare products.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and haircare products

loans.name: Marta

texts.es: Marta C. D. M. resiD. en el departamento D. Sonsonate. Marta tiene 51 años D. edad, es una persona muy trabajadora y religiosa, vive con su esposo quien trabaja como motorista D. transporte público y sus hijas D. 16 y 5 años D. edad. Marta tiene una en su casa la cual ha instalado después D. muchos sacrificios y ahorros que hicieron con su esposo, la tienda tiene tan solo tres años, el crédito que solicita Marta es para surtir su negocio y para poder seguir apoyando a su esposo con los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Marta C. D. M. lives in the department of Sonsonate. She is 51 years old and a very hardworking and religious person. Marta lives with her husband, who works as a public transportation driver, and their two daughters (ages 16 and 5).

She manages a grocery store out of her home. Marta started her business after undertaking many sacrifices and utilizing her husband’s savings. Her store has now been open for three years. She is requesting a loan to restock her business so that she can continue helping her husband with the family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: San Vicente (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal San Vicente se encuentra a unos 45 minutos fuera de la Ciudad de Cuenca en  el Sur del País  en la comunidad del mismo nombre,  su clima frio favorece la agricultura y ganadería,   tiene paisajes hermosos que atrae al turista nacional y extranjero, su gente es sencilla amable y con un corazón muy cálido.     

La señora Rosa Beatriz C. D. vive en la comunidad San Vicente, es una de las socias fundadoras de su banco comunal,  ella  tiene 48 años de edad es casada y tiene cuatro  hijos de 27, 25, 21, 11 años, sus dos  hijos mayores ya son  casados, sólo vive con su último hijo que aun estudia en la primaria,  su tercer hijo estudia y trabaja  en la ciudad  de Cuenca ya que en la noche se dificulta su traslado a casa, su esposo vive en el extranjero desde hace varios años y con su trabajo en el exterior lograron  construir su casa.

Rosa trabaja en el bordado hace veinte años y nos cuenta que le va bien porque ya cuenta con clientela fija que solicita pedidos de bordados principalmente para las polleras (vestimenta nativa de las mujeres de Cuenca, blusas, además se dedica a la cría de pollos, cuyes, borregos, chanchos y vacas, sus animales los comercializa en su misma comunidad.
 
Rosa lleva cuatro años realizando prestamos en la fundación y asegura que los créditos le han permitido salir adelante con sus hijos,  con el nuevo préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue lo va a invertir en la compra de materiales para construir una  casa para su hijo.

Su meta es llegar a comprar un auto para su hijo que está sólo en  la ciudad Cuenca y pueda llegar a casa por la noche.

La señora María Dolores C. es otra socia del banco comunal San Vicente, vive en la comunidad del mismo nombre, tiene 39 años de edad, vive en unión libre y tiene cuatro hijos de 19, 16, 14, 12 años, su hija mayor  le ayuda en el  bordando, el segundo trabaja en una taller de carpintería, el tercer hijo le ayuda en casa con el cuidado de los animales y su último hijo estudia en el colegio Victoria de Portete,  su vivienda es propia que la construyó  su esposo que trabaja en la construcción.

María trabaja en el negocio familiar de bordados lleva catorce años ejerciendo esta actividad y nos comenta que ya tiene su clientela fija que le llevan los trabajos a su casa,  también se dedica a la ganadería  y cría de animales como pollos, cuyes, la leche que obtiene de su ganado entrega a los carros lecheros mientras que sus animales son  para su consumo y para la venta en la Feria Libre  (Mercado de la ciudad de Cuenca).

Este es su cuarto ciclo trabajando con la FUNDACION ESPOIR con  los créditos recibidos compró su ganado y con el nuevo préstamos que obtenga  lo va a invertir en la compra de hierba para su ganado ya que por la sequía que existe no hay suficiente pasto para su alimetnación y un poco de dinero para cubrir unos gastos de su casa.

Su meta es  arreglar su casa y comprarse un auto.
texts.en:
The San Vicente community bank is about 45 minutes outside the city of Cuenca in Southern Ecuador. San Vicente has a cold climate that favors agriculture, and beautiful scenery that attracts domestic and foreign tourists. The people of San Vincente are simple and kind.

Mrs. Rosa Beatriz C. D. lives in San Vicente and is one of the founding members of its community bank. She is 48 years old, is married, and has four children ages 11, 21, 25, and 27. Rosa lives alone with her last child who is still studying in primary school. Her two older children are now married and her third child studies and works in the city of Cuenca. Rosa's husband lived abroad for several years to save money to build their house in San Vicente.

Rosa has worked in embroidery for twenty years. Her business is doing well due to a steady clientele that orders embroidered skirts and blouses (a native clothing of Cuenca). Rose also raises chickens, guinea pigs, sheep, pigs and cattle, and sells the animals in her community.

Rosa has spent four years working with the loan foundation and says that the new loan that you submit to the Fundación Espoir will be invested in buying materials to build a house for her son.

Rosa's goal is also to buy a car for her son who works and studies in Cuenca so he can get home at night.

Ms. María Dolores C. is another member of the Saint Vincent community bank. She is 39 years old and married with four children ages 12, 14, 16, and 19. Her eldest daughter is a knitting aid, the second works in a carpentry workshop, the third son helps with the care of the family's animals at home, and the youngest son is studying in school in Portete del Victoria. The family lives in a house that was built by María's husband, who works in construction.

María works in the family business and has fourteen years of embroidery experience. She tells us that she has a steady clientele that brings work to her home and that she is also engaged in raising and selling livestock, such as chickens and guinea pigs, and selling milk obtained from cattle dairy delivery trucks. The family's animals are for consumption and for sale at Cuenca's open air market.

This is María's fourth loan working with the Fundación Espoir. She will use her livestock to obtain new loans that she will invest in the purchase of grass for her livestock. Because of drought, there is not enough grass for nutrition. The money will also be used to cover some costs of their home.

María's goal is to a build a new home and buy a car.

Translated from Spanish by Bryce Holland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to build a hold and purchase fodder to feed her livestock

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
La señora Sara es la secretaria D. la alcancía comunal "María Auxiliadora", lleva trabajando con EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD por más D. 2 años, tiempo en que ha crecido, cumpliendo metas y proponiéndose otras nuevas.
Sara es madre D. 6 hijos, todos ya son independientes, aunque siempre buscan a su madre para estar en su compañía o para escuchar una voz D. ayuda.
Hace algunos atrás cuando sus hijos aun eran pequeño, como la mayoría D. las madres, era ama D. casa pero siempre tenia el deseo que hacer otras cosas, pasaron los años y el mayor D. sus hijos comenzó a trabajar en Topy Top, porque tenia que hacerse responsable D. su hijo que pronto iba a nacer, pero, al mismo tiempo en que su pareja iba a dar a luz, el hijo D. Sara se enferma D. los bronquios, llegando a estar muy grave, entonces Sara, una buena, madre tuvo que buscar como sanar a su hijo y comenzó a venD. menú, con el fin D. obtener ganancias con las que compraría las medicinas para su hijo y a la vez para el cuidado D. su nuera y su nieto.
Fue un tiempo difícil que supero para el bien D. todos, ahora después D. un tiempo ella aun continua vendiendo menú en su casa por descubrió que es una manera fácil y entretenida D. hacer dinero, en todo el tiempo trabajando ya se compro su cocina, su refrigeradora, y otros instrumentos D. cocina.
Ahora su gran sueño es tener un minimarket y un restaurante, sueño que dentro D. poco será una meta, y meta que cumplirá gracias a su esfuerzo y perseverancia.
texts.en:
Sra. Sara is the secretary of the María Auxiliadora Communal Bank, which has been working with EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD for more than 2 years. The group has grown over time, with the members completing their goals and proposing new ones.

Sara is the mother of 6 children. Even though they are adults, they still look to their mother for company or as a voice of support that will listen to them. Like most mothers, she was a homemaker when her children were still young. However, she had the desire to do other things. After many years passed, her oldest son began working at Topy Top (a Latin American chain of apparel stores) because his partner was about to give to their child and he wanted to be responsible. After the baby was born, Sara’s son developed a serious case of bronchitis. Being a good mother, Sara began selling prepared meals during his recovery so that she could purchase his medicines and look after her daughter-in-law and grandchild.

Even though this was a difficult time, everything turned out well in the end. Sara continues to sell meals out of her home because she found it to be an easy and enjoyable way to make money. She spends most of the time working out of her kitchen, utilizing her refrigerator and cooking utensils. Sara now hopes to open both a mini-market and a restaurant. With her hard work and perseverance, she knows she can fulfill this goal.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more chickens from far villages and sell them in town

loans.name: God Comes First Group

texts.en:
Felecia F. is a leader of a group of four borrowers called God Comes First. She is a youth without a child, but fending for herself through business. Her education level is eighth grade. She lives in the Frog Island Community in Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells at retail to residents of Frog Island Community. Felecia has been running this business for two years, and is hoping to expand her business into a shop. Bad road conditions is a difficulty Felecia faces when transporting goods from wholesale to her business site. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to always come to patronize her business. 

She needs this loan to purchase new kinds of goods to improve her business. Felecia dreams of building a house for her family in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase new kinds of goods to improve her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 34 years old she is married and has three children. Two are in school while the last born is still breastfeeding. She is very hardworking and supportive to her husband in providing food and shelter for her household. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk and biscuits etc. in her neighborhood. She also sews clothing and gives her customers a new look. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, linen etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her husband in taking care of the home and their educational needs. She has been in this business for six years now.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water and boxes of biscuit etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is thirty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercially dominated community.

Grace is a hardworking young woman. She is a food vendor who prepares and sells rice with stew which she sells on a table by the roadside in the mornings.

Grace procures bags of rice and other ingredients from nearby towns. She has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to procure rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice in bulk

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 28 years-old and married with no children. She resides in a rented one room house where she stays with five people. Sarah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

Sarah is a tailor in Makerere Kikoni zone.  She sews all types of clothes and knits sweaters. She incurs transport costs from shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala City. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works six days a week, receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses are feeding her family and accommodation. Her major business challenges are transportation of clothing materials and defaulters. Sarah has been in this business for ten years and with Kiva partner MCDT for two years and is now servicing her fourth loan, working with the same group mates.  Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more cloth and thread.  She hopes to see her business grow bigger so she can sell only wholesale  and start a tailoring school.

loans.use: To buy cloth and thread.

loans.name: Mrs. Kunthea Koem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of seventeen people, is located in Srei Snam village in Kandal province. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Kunthea K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Kunthea K. is a seamstress in her village and her husband, Mr. Vanra Cheab, is a farmer who owns 2-hectares (5-acres) of land which he cultivates to support his family.

This family has a problem because their plow is broken but they do not have enough money to fix it. Thus, Mrs. Kunthea K. decided to ask for a loan to repair the plow.

Mrs. Kunthea K. is the mother of two children who are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To repair her plow

loans.name: God Gee Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'God Gee' group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs from the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. These entrepreneurs want a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person to further strengthen their businesses.

Aminata T. is the leader of this group of  entrepreneurs. Born in Bo city in southern Sierra Leone, the 45-year-old Aminata is married in Magburaka to a businessman and they have 9 children, 7 of whom are attending school – 3 in primary school and 4 in secondary school. Aminata has been a businesswoman for 5 years now. She sells Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), flour, pepper, salt, oil, etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business in size and quality by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale and retail them in Magburaka. 

(On the right of the photo is the Loan Officer, Abdul Karim Conteh, handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy Maggi, flour, pepper, salt, oil, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Paying for seeds and field labor

loans.name: Leonida's Group

texts.en:
Leonida D. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Leonida is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Leonida is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a tailoring business in the local community. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita O. is from the village of Brgy. Darubba, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 43 years old. Anita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Anita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2008, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Anita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets to raise & sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Anita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise & sell

loans.name: Kassissan

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail de tubercules d'ignames, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2002, sa clientèle  est composée de personnes de tout âge. Elle fait face en ce moment en une baisse de son stock de marchandises, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat 20 tas de tubercules d'ignames. Elle  est mariée et mère de 4 enfants
texts.en:
This lady has an income-generating activity selling yam tubers. She has been carrying out this activity since 2002. Her customer base is made up of people of all ages. At present she is experiencing a decline in her stock of goods. She is thus requesting a loan for the purchase of 20 piles of yam tubers. She is married and mother to four children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of yam tubers

loans.name: Nkonim Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Adwoa M. is a determined 59-year-old woman.  She has seven children ranging in age from 14 to 30.  Her husband is a painter. Adwoa M. has been engaged in the retail sale of seedlings and liquid soap for the past 7 years.  Adwoa will use the loan to buy more seedlings and liquid soap to grow her business.  She also would like to provide her children with educational opportunities, so that they can have better job opportunities in the future. 
 
Adwoa M. is currently the leader of the trust bank group named "Nkonim", which means “victory ” in Twi, the most commonly spoken language in Ghana.  There are six members of the group.  The other members of the group include second-hand clothing sellers, hairdressers, and clothes retailers, etc.  They plan to use the loan to purchase assorted stock to grow their businesses and be able to better support their families and their kids' education.

loans.use: To purchase more seedlings and liquid soap

loans.name: Sueños De Emprendedores Group

texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Sueños de los Emprendedores” and this is the second time it has a loan published on Kiva. The members of this group are from the city of Temuco. They are involved in dessert-making, sewing, running a book store, a general store, and selling chocolates, household materials, clothing and undergarments, fruit and flowers.

The group member for this interview was Elizabeth, who is the group’s treasurer. In the photo she is in the front row, on the left, in a green sweater, holding the hand of one of her associate’s sons.
